questions.text: A 32 - year- old female presents to her physician for some advice on fluid replacement during and after running a marathon. She has no known medical history and does not take any regular medications. She has no known allergies, and she denied any family history of cardiac diseases, including sudden cardiac death. On examination, blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, heart rate 65/minute, and oxygen saturation is normal. Auscultation with a stethoscope shows no murmurs, and there is no palpable left ventricular apical impulse. If this patient drank an excessive amount of pure distilled water after the marathon, which of the following effects could be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

During a marathon, ADH is secreted from the posterior pituitary to conserve volume. It inserts aquaporin channel into the collecting duct to increase water resorption from urine. In this runner, rapid ingestion of a large volume of free water can lead to hyponatremia. If the change in plasma osmolarity is rapid, it can cause a potentially fatal cerebral edema when fluid moves from the extracellular to the intracellular fluid compartment. To maintain plasma osmolarity, ADH release is inhibited, causing fewer aquaporin channels to be inserted in the collecting duct and resulting in less water resorption from urine, reduced urine osmolarity, and increased urine volume.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital with substernal, crushing chest pain. She is emergently moved to the cardiac catheterization lab where she undergoes cardiac angiography. Angiography reveals that the diameter of her left anterior descending artery (LAD) is 50% of normal. If her blood pressure, LAD length, and blood viscosity have not changed, which of the following represents the most likely change in LAD flow from baseline?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The flow through a vessel is inversely proportional to resistance. Since resistance is also inversely proportional to the radius raised to the fourth power, this patient will have a 93.75% decrease in LAD flow. This relationship is dictated by Pouiseuille's equation = (pi*pressure difference*radius^4)/(8*viscosity*length) 

The flow through a vessel can be calculated by dividing the pressure gradient (P1 – P2) by the resistance exerted by the walls of the vessel. Furthermore, resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the radius of the vessel. Clinically, this means that small stenoses in blood vessels can lead to dramatic decreases in the amount of blood that reaches a tissue. In this patient, the radius of her LAD is decreased by ½ so the flow through the LAD will be decreased to 1/16 of baseline. This can also be expressed by saying that flow is diminished by 93.75%.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to her physician complaining of difficulty in walking. On questioning, the patient indicates she had trouble walking for 5 days last month and also that she has experienced pain and prickly sensations that come and go, as well as occasional muscle weakness. Vital Signs: T 36.5°C, P 70/min, R 15/min, BP 124/80 mm Hg, BMI 27. Muscle strength testing: Normal. Deep tendon reflexes: Normal. When asked to walk, the patient had difficulty in balancing and maintaining a normal gait. Patellar tendon reflexes were normal. The muscles, however, were weak. LABORATORY STUDIES- MRI indicated Gd-enhancing brain lesions, as well as one infratentorial lesion and three periventricular lesions in the brain. Analysis of cerebrospinal fluid showed an oligoclonal IgG band. During the initial stages of this disease, how would the velocity of action potential transmission be altered within the central nervous system?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Myelinated axons would show a decreased conduction velocity, and unmyelinated axons would show no change in conduction velocity.
Multiple sclerosis is thought to be an autoimmune disease that leads to loss of myelin from central nervous system axons. The lost myelin is replaced by scar tissue called sclerosis. The central nervous system damage results in multiple lesions that are visible on magnetic resonance imaging. Demyelinating diseases diminish the speed of axonal transmission. Consequently, this negatively impacts the coordinated and sequential activation of motor neurons necessary for walking. The difficulty in walking is likely due to damage to the myelinated axons of the basal ganglia or the cerebellum. Deep tendon reflexes are normal because the neuromuscular transmission is working normally in the early stage of the disease. Similarly, muscle weakness may not be apparent. However, over time, the degeneration of the nerves will lead to muscle atrophy and weakness.

questions.text: Given below are four examples of transport across the cell membrane with the type of transport. Which of the following is incorrect?

Absorption of glucose from the intestinal lumen into the intestinal epithelial cells is by Na+- glucose co-transport, an example of secondary active co-transport. 
Glucose is transported into adipocytes by insulin-dependent facilitated diffusion. 
Movement of Ca++ from cardiac muscle cell to the ECF during muscle relaxation is by Na+-Ca++ antiport, which is an example of secondary active counter transport. 
During the depolarization phase of the action potential opening of voltage gated sodium channels allows the influx of sodium. Transport through channels is an example of simple diffusion.

questions.text: A primigravida woman at 33 weeks gestation has been diagnosed with diabetes mellitus. She is rushed to delivery because of signs of preeclampsia. After a caesarean section delivery, the new-born baby is noted to have signs of cyanosis, tachypnoea, and dyspnoea. Which of the following is a characteristic of the substance that is insufficient in the baby?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

This neonate is suffering from neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) caused by a lack of surfactant. It reduces surface tension by disrupting the intermolecular forces (hydrogen bonds) between molecules of water. This prevents small alveoli from collapsing and increases compliance. Synthesis of surfactant is decreased by insulin. Thus, maternal diabetes is also a risk factor for RDS in infants, because fetal hyperglycemia stimulates an increased release of insulin.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man, while laughing at the dinner table during his meal, begins to choke and is starting to turn blue. Fortunately you are present at a nearby table. The following statements are true regarding the initial management of this patient:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The Heimlich manoeuvre should be attempted..
Sol:
•    On the basis of the patient’s blue appearance, his sudden choking, and the fact that he was laughing while eating, it is most likely that he has inhaled a foreign body, and not swallowed. it. This is a case of foreign body aspiration. 
•    An inhaled foreign body is a medical emergency which can affect anyone and can occur when least expected. Any medical practitioner should be confident in the  basic emergency treatment of a choking patient.
•    This is a case which would benefit from the Heimlich manoeuvre, which should be continued until the patient either recovers or becomes unconscious.
•    Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) involves giving two breaths and 30 chest compressions. This is of no use in this case, as the patient’s airway is blocked and no breaths will reach his lungs. Performing chest compressions will only continue to pump increasingly deoxygenated blood to the brain. The Heimlich manoeuvre is required here. This involves standing behind the patient with the patient leaning slightly forward. The physician’s arms should be placed around the patient, so that the hands are clasped just below the patient’s costal margin in the midline. A sudden, strong, inward and upward thrust must be made using the hands to replicate the patient’s natural cough mechanism and help to clear the airway.
•    Obstruction of the larynx must be cleared within a few minutes, otherwise the resulting laryngospasm will most certainly kill the patient. On the other hand, if a foreign body is obstructing one of the two bronchi, the other bronchus may still allow oxygenation of blood for a short time before the signs of hyperinflation and subsequent pneumothorax become apparent.

questions.text:
A 42 year old patient singer by profession has been vigorously practicing for an important concert of his life.  He has subsequently developed hoarse voice. On fiberoptic laryngoscopy, he is found to have adduction of false vocal cords while phonating.

Dysphonia plica ventricularis.
Ref: Read the text below.
Sol:-
•    Dysphonia Plica Ventricularis is the production of sound from false vocal cords.
•    Mogiophonia is speech defect in public appearance only

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with past history of rheumatic fever (20 years back) that was treated with antibiotics. She is asymptomatic. Her physical examination shows a heart rate of 70 beats per minute with a blood pressure of 122/77 mm Hg. She has no jugular venous distention. Her lungs are clear. She has a regular rate and rhythm with a loud S1. A soft early diastolic rumble is heard at the apex with an opening snap after S2. There is wide separation between A2 and the opening snap. No peripheral edema is present. Which of the following is the most appropriate next recommendation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The patient’s examination is consistent with rheumatic mitral stenosis. Severity of her mitral stenosis is mild based on her examination, and she is asymptomatic. Current guidelines recommend antibiotic prophylaxis for secondary prevention in patients with rheumatic fever and carditis. Diuretic therapy is recommended for patients with symptoms of heart failure.

questions.text: 25-year-old male presents to an ENT clinic with sensorineural deafness. He has no history of ear infection or any illicit drug use in the past. Systemic examination reveals normal Blood pressure. He complains of recurrent loin pain in the past with hematuria. His renal function test reveals elevated Creatinine and urine examination revealed eumorphic RBC’s. other systemic examination is normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Barrter’s syndrome

Barrter’s syndrome is an autosomal recessive inherited channelopathy of the renal tubules causing inhibition of the Na-K-2Cl ATPase pump. This leads to dehydration and can cause renal dysfunction due to tubular defect. It is associated with increased risk of renal calculi due to hypercalciuria. The same pump maintains endolymph concentration in the cochlea and leads to sensorineural deafness.
Renal dysfunction with deafness in a young male can mimic Alport’s syndrome. But Alport’s syndrome causes recurrent hematuria (dysmorphic) due to glomerulonephritis and associated with Lens defect.

questions.text: Very slow, irregular, twisting movement, one movement perpetually blending with another is called:

Involuntary movements indicate defect of Basal Ganglia Complex. The common ones are:

A. Athetosis is usually due to defect in the Putamen. It is slow sinuous writhing movement resembling a CRAWLING movement of distal upper limb where one movement blend with another.

B. Chorea usually indicates defect of Caudate Nucleus and described as Quasi-purposive (Semi-purposive) movements.

C. Hemiballismus indicates defect of Subthalamic Nucleus and is flinging, violent movement involving proximal joints and can lead to serious accidents/injury.

questions.text: 30-year-old male is incidentally detected to have high BP. His Urine Chloride levels are high. Blood gas analysis revealed Metabolic alkalosis with an unmeasurable Renin levels. Which is the likely cause:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Liddle’s syndrome 

Liddle’s syndrome is a stimulatory defect in eNa+C at the DCT. This leads to a state of Pseudo-Hyperaldosteronism. This causes Urinary Na+ and water reabsorption even in absence of a measurable Renin levels leading to increase in Plasma volume. This leads to development of Hypertension which is often diagnosed incidentally.  Treatment is available in form of Amiloride (which blocks the eNa+ channels) and offers potential cure.
Barrter’s and Gitelman’s syndrome are inhibitory defects of Na-K-2Cl ATPase pump and Na-Cl transporter respectively leading to defect in Na+ and water reabsorption. Hence, both syndromes are associated with dehydration.

questions.text: Respiratory system disorders commonly present with cough. Following statements are true regarding the symptom EXCEPT

Correct Answer (C)

Significant expectoration is common in Interstitial lung disease

Cough is a common symptom of respiratory system disorders. Based on the sputum production, the cases can be classified into “Significant” and “non-significant” expectoration. Normal sputum production is 60-100ml/day. Quantity more than 100ml/day is bronchorrhea. The presence of bronchorrhea, mucopurulent sputum with hemoptysis is significant expectoration. It is common in Airway/parenchymal disorders.
Non-significant expectoration is common feature in Upper respiratory tract infection. It is also seen in Interstitial and Pleural disorders

questions.text: A 70 years old obese gentleman presents to the emergency department with acute onset of breathlessness. He is a known case of type 2 DM for 10-12 years with poor compliance for antidiabetic drugs. He smokes 20 cigarettes/day for the past 40 years. He was diagnosed as COLD and started on bronchodilator inhalation 10 years back, but he has no further follow-up. He gives history of progressive worsening of breathlessness which is associated with exertion for past 6 months. What is best test in the emergency room to diagnose heart failure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pro-BNP assay

The patient with acute onset breathlessness has risk factor for COLD (Chronic smoker) as well as Ischemic heart disease (Male gender, age, Obesity, uncontrolled DM). Hence it is important to first differentiate between Cardiac and respiratory causes of the symptom.
Breathlessness related to exertion is characteristic of Cardiac cause. In the given case, considering a decade of COLD, progression to Cor pulmonale is suggested once the symptoms correlate with exertion. Cor pulmonale is Right ventricular strain due to severe underlying lung disease. 
In emergency room, Pro-BNP assay results are available in 7 minutes and is an approved biomarker for Heart failure.

questions.text: Increased FEV1/FVC ratio with Reduced DLCO suggests following pathology

Restrictive lung diseases based on DLCO (Diffusion capacity of lung to carbon monoxide) are divide into parenchymal and extra-parenchymal causes. If the DLCO is reduced, it indicates a parenchymal cause (e.g. ILD). Presence of Normal DLCO would suggest Extra-parenchymal causes (e.g. kyphoscoliosis, ankylosing spondylosis)

questions.text: Which of the following broad spectrum anti-arrhythmic drug is most preferred in the emergency management of tachy-arrythmias?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Amiodarone

Ref: Read the text below

Sol: 
•    Though amiodarone can cause QT interval prolongation, it is least likely to cause torsades de pointes.
•    The proposed reason is that even though it is a class III anti-arrhythmic drug, it has additional properties belonging to all other classes of action and hence potent. 
•    Pure class III drugs are more pro-arrhythmic than amiodarone 
•    Due to high potency and lowest risk of TDP among the broad spectrum drugs, it is most preferred in the emergency use of tachy-arrythmias

questions.text: A patient has bronchogenic carcinomas of lung as shown in picture. Which of the following is following clinical features is most probable in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pancoast tumors are peripheral bronchogenic carcinomas that produce symptoms by involvement of extrapulmonary structures adjacent to the cupula. These structures include the nerve roots of C8 and T1, as well as the sympathetic trunk. Interruption of the cervical sympathetic trunk leads to miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis, the triad of signs that constitutes Horner syndrome. Involvement of the nerve roots causes pain along the corresponding dermatomes. The peripheral location of the neoplasm makes pulmonary signs, such as atelectasis, cough, and hemoptysis, unlikely.

questions.text: During cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), what does a sudden increase in the end-tidal carbon dioxide (ETCO2) level indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A Return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC)


A sudden abrupt rise of ETCO2 while performing CPR indicated restarting of the spontaneous circulation and improved blood flow to pulmonary circulation.

questions.text: Which of the following inhaled anesthetic agents has the fastest onset and recovery time, making it ideal for day care procedures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


Sevoflurane


Desflurane has the fastest onset and recovery due to its low blood-gas partition coefficient, which allows it to be taken up and eliminated rapidly.
This should make desflurane particularly useful in outpatient settings where rapid recovery is desired. 

But desflurane is also most pungent agent leading to high risk of airway complications associated with its use.

Sevoflurane offers a better choice of speed as well as non-pungent agent with better recovery profile.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes is undergoing a hip replacement surgery under general anesthesia. Thirty minutes into the procedure, he suddenly develops hypotension, tachycardia, and a decreased EtCO2. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Air embolism

Explanation:

The sudden onset of hypotension, tachycardia, and a decreased EtCO2 during surgery is highly suggestive of an air embolism, especially in surgeries that involve the use of instruments that can introduce air into the vascular system, such as orthopedic procedures.

choices.text: Place the patient in reverse Trendelenburg position

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient is scheduled for a total hip replacement under spinal anesthesia. Shortly after the administration of the spinal anesthetic, the patient develops hypotension and bradycardia. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Administer intravenous fluids

• Hypotension following spinal anesthesia is common due to the sympathetic blockade leading to vasodilation.

• The initial management typically involves changing the position of the patient to Trendelenburg position causing return of blood in
the venous capacitance vessels of lower limbs.

• Then administering intravenous fluids to increase preload.

• If the hypotension persists or is severe, vasopressors may be necessary.

• Bradycardia can be managed with atropine if needed, but the first line is to address the hypotension.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory failure. His SpO2 is 85% on room air. Which of the following oxygen delivery devices is most appropriate for initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Venturi mask

 
Rationale: A Venturi mask is ideal for COPD patients as it allows for precise control of FiO2, minimizing the risk of oxygen-induced hypercapnia, which can occur if  the patient’s hypoxic drive is suppressed by excessive oxygen.

questions.text: Your patient is convinced that she has cancer. She is clearly agitated and is complaining of pain in her abdomen. A workup for cancer is negative, yet your patient refuses to accept the diagnosis and becomes increasingly anxious and expresses an intense sense of impending doom. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Paroxetine 


Paroxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), an antidepressant, and is the drug of choice for treating this patient’s depression. Carbamazepine (choice A), is an anticonvulsant and mood stabilizer which may be used to treat bipolar disorder. Methylphenidate (choice B) is a CNS stimulant; olanzapine (choice C) is an atypical antipsychotic.

questions.text: A patient was observed in her room alone talking loudly and gesticulating, this is probably an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hallucination


Hallucination refers to perception without sensory input. The patient is having a conversation and gesticulating to someone who is not in the room. Delusion (choice A) refers to false belief (not perception) that is not amenable to reason. In obsessive-compulsive behaviour (choice C), the patient recognizes the irrationality of the compulsion, but not engaging in it causes extreme anxiety. In panic states, the patient experiences extreme anxiety, usually immobilizing or forcing him/her to escape from the situation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a suicide predictor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Adolescence

Adolescent age is not considered a risk factor for suicide. (Ref: Kaplan)

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was seen by a school counselor after the teachers complained of his behavior in school. He frequently becomes angry towards others and loses his temper in class. His parents report that at home, he refuses to comply with house rules, often stays up later than he is supposed to, and frequently talks back to them. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Oppositional defiant disorder
Children with oppositional defiant disorder usually have problems with authority figures such as parents and teachers. Unlike children with conduct disorder, they do not break rules of society and do not commit crimes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman was recently seen by her primary care physician due to complaints of depressed mood, lack of pleasure, sleep problems, decreased appetite and weight, decreased energy, and problems with concentration. She states that these symptoms started when she was fired from her job about 4 weeks ago, and that since then, she has been unable to function. What is the most indicated treatment at this time?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Paroxetine
She has a diagnosis of major depression and the first line treatment is the use of an SSRI medication because of a better side-effect profile compared to the other therapies. Bupropion, would be useful but not the first choice. Alprazolam is simply a benzodiazepine and acts as an anxiolytic, not an antidepressant. Electroconvulsive therapy might be useful if initial therapy did not work or the depression was far more severe and was associated with psychotic features.

questions.text: Which of the following is not corresponding to the biochemical changes in pre-eclampsia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Reduced sFlt-1 levels

In Pre-Eclampsia, sFlt-1 levels are increased. It is called as soluble FMS like tyrosine kinase 1. It reduces the action of VEGF. VEGF is known to have vasodilation effect. So sFlt-1 increment is known to cause vasoconstriction and hence hypertension.

questions.text: Which one of the following is a part of diagnostic criteria for the diagnosis of HELLP syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Raised LDH
1) Hemolysis confirmed with at least 2 of the findings:
•    Peripheral smear with schistocytes and burr cells
•    Serum indirect bilirubin >1.2 mg/dl
•    Low serum haptoglobin(<25mg/dl) or LDH> two times the upper level of the normal.
•    Unexplained anemia
2) Elevated liver enzymes: AST or ALT > 2 times the upper level of normal.
3) Low platelets: <100,000 cells/microL.

questions.text: A 23 years old primigravida has 37 weeks of gestation. Which one of the following would be a considered as parameter of contracted-pelvis?
questions.solution:

Transverse diameter of inlet is 11 cm

If the transverse diameter of the inlet is less than 12 cm or if the obstetric conjugate of inlet is less than 10cm or if the diagonal conjugate is less than 11.5cm then it is called as INLET CONTRACTION.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not considered as physiological change in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Goitre

Pedl oedema is physiological since it is due to physiological hypoproteinaemia and IVC compression by uterus. Hyperinsulinemia and increased insulin resistance are normally seen in pregnancy due to diabetogenic effect of multiple hormones especially HPL. Sr, Fibrinogen is called as Factor 1 and it is increased by 50 %. There is no goitre seen in a normal pregnancy.

choices.text: She must take folic acid supplement of 4000mcg as soon as she becomes pregnant
She must take folic acid supplement of 400 mcg for at least 1 month before attempting pregnancy

questions.text: A 28 years old nulliparous patient has a history of an abortion of 12 weeks and the fetus was found to have anencephaly. She is planning for the next pregnancy. What should be done by her to avoid having another such baby?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

She must take folic acid supplement of 4000 mcg for at least 3 months before attempting pregnancy

Since this patient is having a history of NTD in past pregnancy, she has high risk of recurrence of the same thing in next pregnancy. For prevention of the same, she must take 400mcg for at least 3 months before attempting pregnancy.

questions.text: A 26 years old female G2P1L1 with history of previous caesarean section presents to the ER. She is hypotensive, Fetal heart sounds are absent and fetal parts are easily palpable. What is her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Uterine rupture

Oligohydramnios will not develop maternal shock, Abruption will cause stony hard uterus and fetal parts will be difficult to palpate, Complete mole has no fetus. This is a case of uterine rupture due to previous scar of lower segment on the uterus. Fetus is out of the uterus so it is easily palpable.

questions.text: Which of the following finding is most specific for true labour pains?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cervical dilation

Pain may be due to false labour, blood tinged discharge could be due to infection or local pathology, frequent urge to pass urine could be due to UTI but cervical dilation is specific for true labour.

questions.text: A 23 years old primigravida has come to the OPD at 16 weeks of gestation. Which of the following investigations would not correspond to the diagnosis of OVERT DM?

questions.text: Which of the following complications would not be associated with GDM?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Congenital anomalies

Congenital anomalies are not seen in a case of GDM because this is a disease of the later half of pregnancy. Organogenesis is not affected by this since it is over in first trimester.

questions.text: A 29 years old G2P1L1 has come to the ANC opd for the first time at 19 weeks. Which of the following investigations would not be suitable for her in this ANC visit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Group B streptococcal screening

Group B streptococcal screening is done in the third trimester at 35-37 weeks. It is meant for prevention of neonatal infection by GBS. It is not done in second trimester at 19 weeks.

questions.text: As per Anemia Mukt Bharat Program, the therapeutic doses of iron deficiency anemia and folic acid deficiency anemia in pregnancy is?

questions.text: During the third stage of labour, the following procedure was done. It is called as?

Modified Brandt Andrews method

This is controlled cord traction by modified Brandt Andrew method. It is done by pulling the cord with one hand and pushing the uterus with other hand abdominally. It is a part of AMTSL guideline.

questions.text: The following picture is seen in wet mount preparation of a 23 years old woman with vaginal discharge. Which of the following is matching with this clinical case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fishy foul smell is present

This is a case of bacterial vaginosis. In this case, there is an overgrowth of anaerobic flora in vagina along with reduction of lactobacilli. There is no inflammation at all. It is not a sexually transmitted infection. There is fishy foul smell and the most common cause is Gardnerella vaginalis.

questions.text: What is the name of the following tubal ligation method?
questions.solution:

Uchida

This is UCHIDA technique. In this method, the tubal serosa is opened, fallopian tube is ligated and cut. The medial end is buried under the tubal serosa. It has no failure rate.

questions.text: A 63 years old multiparous patient has come with history of post-menopausal bleeding since last 3 months. On per speculum examination, the following finding was noted. Which of the following is next line of investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Direct punch biopsy

If there is a lesion which is visible on cervix then we must do a punch biopsy. If there is no lesion then we must take a pap smear plus do TVS for knowing the cause of postmenopausal bleeding.

questions.text: A 25 years old nulliparous patient underwent USG of pelvis and the following picture was seen in her uterus. Which hormone is responsible for this picture?

Estrogen

This is a picture of trilaminar endometrium (triple line). This is seen in proliferative phase. Estrogen is responsible for proliferation of endometrium.

questions.text: A 22 years old P1L1 patient has an ovarian cyst of 8*8cm sized. Usg is suggestive of ROKITANSKY PROTRUBERANCE. Which of the following is the most likely ovarian tumour?
questions.solution:

Benign cystic teratoma

Benign cystic teratoma is dermoid cyst. It has teeth, bone, sebum etc. In USG, there is hyperechoic material seen due to hard substance in dermoid. This is called as ROKITANSKY protuberance.

questions.text: Which of the following complications is not seen with the given anatomical anomaly of the uterus?

Recurrent transverse lie

This is HSG of unicornuate uterus. It is formed from one MULLERIAN duct instead of two MULLERIAN ducts. The shape is such that it won’t allow transverse lie at all.

questions.text: Hysteroscopy is the treatment of choice for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

FIGO-1 fibroid

ENDOMETRIOSIS, BICORNUATE UTERUS and FIGO-7 fibroid are treated by laparoscopy. FIGO-0 and FIGO -1 are treated by hysteroscopy since these fibroids are submucosal.

questions.text: A 26 years old PCOS patient is taking the following medications for the treatment: Metformin, Myoinositol, Cholecalciferol, Inj. HMG. Which one of these is responsible for ascites, rapid weight gain and severe abdominal pain with breathlessness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Inj. HMG

The signs and symptoms mentioned in the question are seen in ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. Highest risk of this syndrome is seen with gonadotropin therapy. Inj. HMG is human menopausal gonadotropin.

questions.text: In which of the following causes of short stature is bone age consistent with a patient's actual age?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Familial short stature

Reference: Nelson’s textbook of Pediatrics

Bone age correlates well with stage of pubertal development and can be helpful in predicting adult height in early- or late-maturing adolescents. In familial short stature, the bone age is normal (comparable to chronologic age). In constitutional delay, endocrinologic short stature, and undernutrition, the bone age is low and comparable to the height age.

choices.text: Reassure the parents and follow up after 6 months

questions.text: A 6 years old child comes with complain of bedwetting. The child is continent during the day and problem is only at night. Growth and development are normal. Urine microscopy is normal and urine specific gravity is 1.020. How will you manage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Reassure the parents and follow up after 6 months

Reference: Nelson’s textbook
Active treatment should be avoided in children younger than 6 years of age, because enuresis is extremely common in younger children. Treatment is more likely to be successful in children approaching puberty compared with younger children. In addition, treatment is most likely to be effective in children who are motivated to stay dry. Treatment should be viewed as a facilitator that requires active participation by the child (e.g., a coach and an athlete).

questions.text: At what age would a child with no teeth be considered to have delayed eruption?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

13 months

Reference: Nelson's textbook of Pediatrics

Delayed eruption is usually considered when there are no teeth by approximately 13 mo of age (mean + 3 standard deviations). Common causes include hypothyroid, hypoparathyroid, familial, and (the most common) idiopathic disorders

choices.text: Skin to skin contact between mother and baby
Initiated in a facility and continued at home

questions.text: Key features of kangaroo mother care are all the following EXCEPT ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Done for babies with cyanosis

Reference: AIIMS NICU Protocols

Kangaroo Mother Care:

KMC was first suggested in 1978 by Dr Edgar Rey in Bogota, Colombia.

Benefits: A Cochrane review on benefits of KMC demonstrated that:
Improved exclusive breast feeding rates at discharge, at 1-3 months of and a trend towards improved rates at 6-12 months
    Reduction in the risk of mortality 
    Reduction in nosocomial infection/sepsis 
    Reduction in hypothermia
     Reduction in length of hospital stay 
o    Components of KMC 
    Kangaroo position: The kangaroo position consists of skin-to-skin contact (SSC) between the mother and the infant in a vertical position, between the mother’s breasts and under her clothes
    Kangaroo nutrition: Kangaroo nutrition is the delivery of nutrition to “kangarooed” infants as soon as oral feeding is possible.
    Kangaroo discharge and follow up
o    When to discontinue KMC? Often this is desirable until the baby's gestation reaches term or the weight is around 2500 g. 
o    Post-discharge follow-up:  Baby is followed once or twice a week till 37-40 weeks of gestation or till the baby reaches 2.5 to 3 kg of weight. Thereafter, a follow up once in 2-4 weeks may be enough till 3 months of post-conception age

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought with history of decreased urine output, cola colored urine and swelling of the face and hands of 2 days duration. He is hypertensive, has a puffy face and pitting edema of the lower limbs. He has history of skin lesions 4 weeks earlier. A diagnosis of post streptococcal glomerulonephritis is made C3 levels are likely to return to normal in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

6-8 weeks

Reference: Pediatric Kidney Disease Textbook, 1st edition

Usually complement levels normalize within 6–8 weeks, if hypocomplementemia persists more than 3 months one should strongly consider an alternative diagnosis (membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis).

questions.text: The renal biopsy of a 6 years old boy with recurrent gross hematuria shows lgA nephropathy. The urinary protein excretion is 130 mg/day. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

None of these

•    Treatment of IgA/ HSP nephritis depends upon whether the patient is a child or an adult and upon the severity of renal manifestations. 

•    Specific treatment of IgA/ HSP nephritis should be considered only in patients with marked proteinuria (>1 g/day) and/or impaired renal function during the acute episode 

•    Patients with limited evidence of renal involvement such as microscopic hematuria, macroscopic hematuria of short duration, or mild proteinuria (<1 g/day) are generally not subjected to renal biopsy and are not given specific therapy but should be followed closely for worsening of proteinuria or impairment of renal function.

questions.text: A 6 month infant presented with recurrent episodes of polyuria and dehydration. Lab test revealed serum Na of 130 meq/L, K of 3 meq/ L, CI- of 92 meq/L, bicarbonate of 30 meq/L. pH was 7.48. Serum creatinine was 0.4 mg/dl. The patient had hypercalciuria and ultrasound showed medullary nephrocalcinosis. Which or following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Bartter syndrome

Bartter syndrome and Gitelman syndrome (also called tubular hypomagnesemia-hypokalemia with hypocalciuria) are autosomal recessive disorders with characteristic sets of metabolic abnormalities. These include hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, hyperreninemia, hyperplasia of the juxtaglomerular apparatus (the source of renin in the kidney), and hyperaldosteronism. Some patients also have hypomagnesemia and/or high levels of prostaglandin E2 (PGE2).

Bartter syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder that often presents in childhood and may be associated with the following clinical features:
●Growth and mental retardation
●Hypokalemia
●Metabolic alkalosis
●Polyuria and polydipsia due to decreased urinary concentrating ability
●Normal to increased urinary calcium excretion
●Normal or mildly decreased serum magnesium concentration

choices.text: Nasal washing for influenza virus and respiratory syncytial virus

questions.text: A 2 yr old boy is presented to the emergency department at 3 AM with a chief complaint of fever and cough. His respiratory rate is 36 breaths/min, his temperature is 39°C, and his pulse oximetry reading is 96%. On physical examination he has a barky cough and stridor only with crying. He is well hydrated, able to drink, and consolable. What is the appropriate next step in patient management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Dexamethasone

The effectiveness of oral corticosteroids in viral croup is well established. Corticosteroids decrease the edema in the laryngeal mucosa through their anti-inflammatory action. Oral steroids are beneficial, even in mild croup, as measured by reduced hospitalization, shorter duration of hospitalization, and reduced need for subsequent interventions such as epinephrine administration.

Most studies that demonstrated the efficacy of oral dexamethasone used a single dose of 0.6 mg/kg; a dose as low as 0.15 mg/ kg may be just as effective. Intramuscular dexamethasone and nebulized budesonide have an equivalent clinical effect; oral dosing of dexamethasone is as effective as intramuscular administration. A single dose of oral prednisolone is less effective. There are no controlled studies examining the effectiveness of multiple doses of corticosteroids

questions.text: On examination of a full-term newborn, the physician notes mild hepatomegaly. Other physical findings are normal, including head circumference and appearance of the retinas. A urine culture grows cytomegalovirus (CMV). Results of head ultrasonography are normal. Subsequent testing discloses no metabolic disorders. The deficit most likely to occur in the next year is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

SNHL
Asymptomatic congenital CMV infection is likely a leading cause of sensorineural hearing loss, which occurs in 7-10% of all infants with congenital CMV infection, whether symptomatic at birth or not.
